Articles.Content: I know holograms require a medium to be beamed onto in order to work, What if a machine generated virtual particles and deflected light off those?
Well, Quantum Physics might have a good solution. Not sure if this question is KSP or Reality oriented. Perhaps Scott Manley knows something about this?

You could try to ask him through Google+, although he may be busy with the kids and YouTube and work. You could give it a shot though ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Virtual particles are a very poor name. They're not particles. They're non-localized disturbances in quantum fields. 

[http://profmattstrassler.com/articles-and-posts/particle-physics-basics/virtual-particles-what-are-they/](http://profmattstrassler.com/articles-and-posts/particle-physics-basics/virtual-particles-what-are-they/)

Read that, he explains it very clearly.

> 
> I know holograms require a medium to be beamed onto in order to work, What if a machine generated virtual particles and deflected light off those?

Rimmer, is that you?

The best we have is this, few years old. Expect better resolution nowdays, but nothing spectacular.

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KfVS-npfVuY?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

And that's not a hologram. Holograms are illusions of 3D and require medium.

> 
> I know holograms require a medium to be beamed onto in order to work, What if a machine generated virtual particles and deflected light off those?

No, you cannot do that. Without getting into details, it'd be a violation of conservation of momentum. You need an actual medium with an actual physical mass to scatter the light from.

> 
> Virtual particles are a very poor name. They're not particles. They're non-localized disturbances in quantum fields.

So are regular particles. ![:rolleyes:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_rolleyes.gif)

That's not what makes virtual particles virtual.
